thread.title: Westlake fatal fire block to be auctioned
thread.title_full: Westlake fatal fire block to be auctioned

author: Alex Tilbury
title: Westlake fatal fire block to be auctioned
text:
FOUR and a half minutes was all it took to change Jillian Ginn’s life forever.
An inferno engulfed Ms Ginn’s timber home in Westlake in the middle of the night on June 15 and claimed the life of her 11-year-old son Edison.
Ms Ginn has now made the tough decision to sell the block of land at 5 Hilliup St, Westlake .
“I scoured through the house to find anything left, and nothing,” said the 44-year-old mother, who is the face of resilience despite her broken heart.
“There was no smoke or heat.”
Only one of the four smoke alarms on her property sounded, which woke the family at 11:30pm. The unexplained fire was in the hardwood walls.
“What happened to us is sad, so sad. Eddie had no ability to manipulate as he was autistic, his love was just so pure,” Ms Ginn said.
Edison’s sisters, Francesca, 13, and Freya-Grace, 10, made the decision easier for their mum to put their house block up for sale, saying it was just too sad for them to stay there and rebuild.
Peter Chew, of RE/MAX Innovation – Jindalee, said the 875sq m block, including the existing pool at 5 Hilliup St, Westlake, would go under the hammer on September 12.
“Here is your chance to design and build your dream home that ticks all your boxes,” he said.
Edison Hellmuth, 11, who was killed in a fire in his Westlake home with his mum Jillian Ginn. Source: Supplied
Ms Ginn, who is now renting a house in Westlake, said it was a wonderful community and a wonderful street.
“The block will suit another family and it is also big enough that you could subdivide,” she said.
“When we moved into this home in January, 2014, I promised my kids a bedroom each, a pool, a cul de sac so they could ride their bikes and I needed privacy as Eddie used to love to jump naked on the trampoline.
“On the morning of the fire we sat on the front veranda and Eddie and I looked at a double rainbow. It was a beautiful one.”
It would have been Edison’s 12th birthday this Sunday, August 30.
“I had three kids in three years and one week, so my children are so close,” Ms Ginn said.
“The level of destruction was total. I spent hours on my hands and knees going over what was Freya-Grace’s bedroom to find one thing that belonged to her. I couldn’t find one thing. Nothing, all gone. We have lost everything.”
Ms Ginn said her bond with Edison was hard to describe.
“The level of attachment we had was completely incomparable to anything else. It’s not like I have just lost a third limb, its much more than that. It’s redefining my family.”
“I am a Christian and he’s still with us without a doubt.”
Ms Ginn, a busy single mum who is the state general manager of IT company Sable 37, said Edison “taught me more in his short life than both of my degrees”.
“The house went up in four-and-a-half minutes. The firies said it was the worst house fire ever seen in Australia. I was sobbing, but when Eddie died he wasn’t all charred, he looked like an angel.”
Donations can be made to:
Edison’s Family Recovery Fund
ANZ Bank
BSB 014 215
Account 294620028
Originally published as Fresh start from the tragic ruins
